statements.name: PROC SQL
statements.description: PROC SQL Statement

arguments.name: _METHOD
arguments.description: displays the hierarchy of execution methods that PROC SQL used in the SQL query. Each step is identified by a code and is displayed in the SAS log.

arguments.name: _TREE
arguments.description: displays a hierarchical representation of how the SQL query was executed.

arguments.name: CONSTDATETIME
arguments.description: specifies whether the SQL procedure replaces references to the DATE, TIME, DATETIME, and TODAY functions in a query with their equivalent constant values before the query executes. Computing these values once ensures consistency of results when the functions are used multiple times in a query or when the query executes the functions close to a date or time boundary.

arguments.name: NOCONSTDATETIME
arguments.description: specifies whether the SQL procedure replaces references to the DATE, TIME, DATETIME, and TODAY functions in a query with their equivalent constant values before the query executes. Computing these values once ensures consistency of results when the functions are used multiple times in a query or when the query executes the functions close to a date or time boundary.

arguments.name: DICTDIAG
arguments.description: specifies whether to create a Diagnostic column in the report. The Diagnostic column in the report contains a message for each DICTIONARY table that failed to open.

arguments.name: NODICTDIAG
arguments.description: specifies whether to create a Diagnostic column in the report. The Diagnostic column in the report contains a message for each DICTIONARY table that failed to open.

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: specifies whether to double-space the report.

arguments.name: NODOUBLE
arguments.description: specifies whether to double-space the report.

arguments.name: DQUOTE=
arguments.description:
specifies whether PROC SQL treats values within double quotation marks (" ") as variables or strings. With DQUOTE=ANSI, PROC SQL treats a quoted value as a variable. This feature enables you to use the following as table names, column names, or aliases:
• reserved words such as                                  AS, JOIN, GROUP, and so on
• DBMS names and other                                  names that are not normally permissible in SAS.

arguments.name: ERRORSTOP
arguments.description: specifies whether PROC SQL stops executing if it encounters an error. In a batch or noninteractive session, ERRORSTOP instructs PROC SQL to stop executing the statements but to continue checking the syntax after it has encountered an error.

arguments.name: NOERRORSTOP
arguments.description: specifies whether PROC SQL stops executing if it encounters an error. In a batch or noninteractive session, ERRORSTOP instructs PROC SQL to stop executing the statements but to continue checking the syntax after it has encountered an error.

arguments.name: EXEC
arguments.description: specifies whether a statement should be executed after its syntax is checked for accuracy.

arguments.name: NOEXEC
arguments.description: specifies whether a statement should be executed after its syntax is checked for accuracy.

arguments.name: EXITCODE
arguments.description: specifies that PROC SQL clears an error code for any SQL statement. Error codes are assigned to the SQLEXITCODE macro variable.

arguments.name: FEEDBACK
arguments.description: specifies whether PROC SQL displays, in the SAS log, PROC SQL statements after view references are expanded or certain other transformations of the statement are made.

arguments.name: NOFEEDBACK
arguments.description: specifies whether PROC SQL displays, in the SAS log, PROC SQL statements after view references are expanded or certain other transformations of the statement are made.

arguments.name: FLOW
arguments.description: specifies that character columns longer than n are flowed to multiple lines. PROC SQL sets the column width at n and specifies that character columns longer than n are flowed to multiple lines. When you specify FLOW=n m, PROC SQL floats the width of the columns between these limits to achieve a balanced layout. Specifying FLOW without arguments is equivalent to specifying FLOW=12 200.

arguments.name: INOBS=
arguments.description: restricts the number of rows (observations) that PROC SQL retrieves from any single source.

arguments.name: IPASSTHRU
arguments.description: specifies whether implicit pass through is enabled or disabled.

arguments.name: NOIPASSTHRU
arguments.description: specifies whether implicit pass through is enabled or disabled.

arguments.name: LOOPS=
arguments.description: restricts PROC SQL to n iterations through its inner loop. You use the number of iterations reported in the SQLOOPS macro variable (after each SQL statement is executed) to discover the number of loops. Set a limit to prevent queries from consuming excessive computer resources. For example, joining three large tables without meeting the join-matching conditions could create a huge internal table that would be inefficient to execute.

arguments.name: NUMBER
arguments.description: specifies whether the SELECT statement includes a column called ROW, which is the row (or observation) number of the data as the rows are retrieved.

arguments.name: NONUMBER
arguments.description: specifies whether the SELECT statement includes a column called ROW, which is the row (or observation) number of the data as the rows are retrieved.

arguments.name: OUTOBS=
arguments.description: restricts the number of rows (observations) in the output. For example, if you specify OUTOBS=10 and insert values into a table using a query expression, then the SQL procedure inserts a maximum of 10 rows. Likewise, OUTOBS=10 limits the output to 10 rows.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: specifies whether the output from a SELECT statement is printed.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: specifies whether the output from a SELECT statement is printed.

arguments.name: PROMPT
arguments.description: modifies the effect of the INOBS=, OUTOBS=, and LOOPS= options. If you specify the PROMPT option and reach the limit specified by INOBS=, OUTOBS=, or LOOPS=, then PROC SQL prompts you to stop or continue. The prompting repeats if the same limit is reached again.

arguments.name: NOPROMPT
arguments.description: modifies the effect of the INOBS=, OUTOBS=, and LOOPS= options. If you specify the PROMPT option and reach the limit specified by INOBS=, OUTOBS=, or LOOPS=, then PROC SQL prompts you to stop or continue. The prompting repeats if the same limit is reached again.

arguments.name: REDUCEPUT=
arguments.description: specifies the engine type to use to optimize a PUT function in a query. The PUT function is replaced with a logically equivalent expression. The engine type can be one of the following values:

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: specifies to consider the optimization of all PUT functions, regardless of the engine that is used by the query to access the data.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies to not optimize any PUT function.

arguments.name: DBMS
arguments.description: specifies to consider the optimization of all PUT functions in a query performed by a SAS/ACCESS engine.

arguments.name: BASE
arguments.description: specifies to consider the optimization of all PUT functions in a query performed by a SAS/ACCESS engine or a Base SAS engine.

arguments.name: REDUCEPUTOBS=
arguments.description: when the REDUCEPUT= option is set to DBMS, BASE, or ALL, specifies the minimum number of observations that must be in a table for PROC SQL to consider optimizing the PUT function in a query.

arguments.name: REDUCEPUTVALUES=
arguments.description: when the REDUCEPUT= option is set to DBMS, BASE, or ALL, specifies the maximum number of SAS format values that can exist in a PUT function expression for PROC SQL to consider optimizing the PUT function in a query.

arguments.name: REMERGE
arguments.description: specifies whether PROC SQL can process queries that use remerging of data. The remerge feature of PROC SQL makes two passes through a table, using data in the second pass that was created in the first pass, in order to complete a query. When the NOREMERGE system option is set, PROC SQL cannot process remerging of data. If remerging is attempted when the NOREMERGE option is set, then an error is written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: NOREMERGE
arguments.description: specifies whether PROC SQL can process queries that use remerging of data. The remerge feature of PROC SQL makes two passes through a table, using data in the second pass that was created in the first pass, in order to complete a query. When the NOREMERGE system option is set, PROC SQL cannot process remerging of data. If remerging is attempted when the NOREMERGE option is set, then an error is written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: SORTMSG
arguments.description: for certain operations, such as ORDER BY, that can sort tables internally using PROC SORT, specifies whether information about the sort can be requested from PROC SORT and displayed in the log.

arguments.name: NOSORTMSG
arguments.description: for certain operations, such as ORDER BY, that can sort tables internally using PROC SORT, specifies whether information about the sort can be requested from PROC SORT and displayed in the log.

arguments.name: SORTSEQ=
arguments.description: specifies the collating sequence to use when a query contains an ORDER BY clause. Use this option only if you want a collating sequence other than your system or installation’s default collating sequence.

arguments.name: STIMER
arguments.description: specifies whether PROC SQL writes timing information to the SAS log for each statement, rather than as a cumulative value for the entire procedure. For this option to work, you must also specify the SAS system option STIMER. Some operating environments require that you specify this system option when you invoke SAS. If you use the system option alone, then you receive timing information for the entire SQL procedure, not on a statement-by-statement basis.

arguments.name: NOSTIMER
arguments.description: specifies whether PROC SQL writes timing information to the SAS log for each statement, rather than as a cumulative value for the entire procedure. For this option to work, you must also specify the SAS system option STIMER. Some operating environments require that you specify this system option when you invoke SAS. If you use the system option alone, then you receive timing information for the entire SQL procedure, not on a statement-by-statement basis.

arguments.name: STOPONTRUNC
arguments.description: specifies to not insert or update a row that contains data larger than the column when a truncation error occurs. This applies only when using the SET clause in an INSERT or UPDATE statement.

arguments.name: THREADS
arguments.description: overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS for a particular invocation of PROC SQL unless the system option is restricted. (See Restriction.) THREADS | NOTHREADS can also be specified in a RESET statement for use in particular queries. When THREADS is specified, PROC SQL uses parallel processing in order to increase the performance of sorting operations that involve large amounts of data. For more information about parallel processing, see .

arguments.name: NOTHREADS
arguments.description: overrides the SAS system option THREADS | NOTHREADS for a particular invocation of PROC SQL unless the system option is restricted. (See Restriction.) THREADS | NOTHREADS can also be specified in a RESET statement for use in particular queries. When THREADS is specified, PROC SQL uses parallel processing in order to increase the performance of sorting operations that involve large amounts of data. For more information about parallel processing, see .

arguments.name: UNDO_POLICY=
arguments.description: specifies how PROC SQL handles updated data if errors occur while you are updating data. You can use UNDO_POLICY= to control whether your changes are permanent.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: keeps any updates or inserts.

arguments.name: OPTIONAL
arguments.description: reverses any updates or inserts that it can reverse reliably.

arguments.name: REQUIRED
arguments.description: reverses all inserts or updates that have been done to the point of the error. In some cases, the UNDO operation cannot be done reliably. For example, when a program uses a SAS/ACCESS view, it might not be able to reverse the effects of the INSERT and UPDATE statements without reversing the effects of other changes at the same time. In that case, PROC SQL issues an error message and does not execute the statement.

arguments.name: UBUFSIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the internal transient buffer page size for the PROC SQL paged memory subsystem. PROC SQL uses this subsystem to help implement operations such as joins, aggregations, and intersections. The output is in multiples of 1 (bytes), 1024 (kilobytes), 1,048,576 (megabytes), or 1,073,741,824 (gigabytes). For example, a value of 65536 specifies a page size of 65536 bytes, and a value of 64k specifies a page size of 65536 bytes.

arguments.name: WARNRECURS
arguments.description: specifies whether a warning displays in the SAS log for recursive references.

arguments.name: NOWARNRECURS
arguments.description: specifies whether a warning displays in the SAS log for recursive references.

statements.name: ALTER TABLE
statements.description: Adds columns to, drops columns from, and changes column attributes in an existing table. Adds, modifies, and drops integrity constraints from an existing table.
statements.help:
ALTER TABLE  table-name
	<ADD column-definition-1<, column-definition-2,  ...>>
	<ADD  CONSTRAINT constraint-name-1constraint-specification-1
		<, constraint-name-2 constraint-specification-2,  ...>>
	<ADD constraint-specification-1<, constraint-specification-2,  ...>>
	<DROP column-1<, column-2,  ...>>
	<DROP CONSTRAINT constraint-name-1<, constraint-name-2,  ...>>
	<DROP FOREIGN KEY constraint-name>
	<DROP PRIMARY KEY >
	<MODIFY column-definition-1<, column-definition-2,  ...>>;

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description:
• in the ALTER TABLE statement, refers to the name of the table that is to be altered.
• in the REFERENCES clause, refers to the name of table that contains the primary key that is referenced by the foreign key.

arguments.name: ADD
arguments.description: adds the column or columns that are specified in each column-definition.

arguments.name: ADD CONSTRAINT constraint-name-1 constraint-specification-1, constraint-name-2 constraint-specification-2,
arguments.description: adds the integrity constraint that is specified in constraint-specification and assigns constraint-name to it.

arguments.name: constraint-name
arguments.description: specifies a name for the constraint that is being specified. The name must be a valid SAS name.

arguments.name: CHECK
arguments.description: specifies that all rows in table-name satisfy the WHERE-clause. WHERE-clausespecifies a SAS WHERE clause. Do not include the WHERE keyword in the WHERE clause.

arguments.name: DISTINCT
arguments.description: specifies that the values of each column must be unique. This constraint is identical to UNIQUE.

arguments.name: FOREIGN
arguments.description: specifies a foreign key, that is, a set of columns whose values are linked to the values of the primary key variable in another table (the table-name that is specified for REFERENCES). The referential-actions are performed when the values of a primary key column that is referenced by the foreign key are updated or deleted.

arguments.name: CASCADE
arguments.description: allows primary key data values to be updated, and updates matching values in the foreign key to the same values. This referential action is currently supported for updates only.

arguments.name: RESTRICT
arguments.description: prevents the update or deletion of primary key data values if a matching value exists in the foreign key. This referential action is the default.

arguments.name: SET
arguments.description: allows primary key data values to be updated, and sets all matching foreign key values to NULL.

arguments.name: NOT
arguments.description: specifies that column does not contain a null or missing value, including special missing values.

arguments.name: PRIMARY
arguments.description: specifies one or more primary key columns (that is, columns that do not contain missing values and whose values are unique).

arguments.name: UNIQUE
arguments.description: specifies that the values of each column must be unique. This constraint is identical to DISTINCT.

arguments.name: message-string
arguments.description: specifies the text of an error message that is written to the log when the integrity constraint is not met. The maximum length of message-string is 250 characters.

arguments.name: NEWLINE
arguments.description: the text that is specified for MESSAGE= is displayed as well as the default error message for that integrity constraint.

arguments.name: USER
arguments.description: only the text that is specified for MESSAGE= is displayed.

arguments.name: ADD constraint-specification-1 , constraint-specification-2,
arguments.description: adds the integrity constraint that is specified in constraint-specification and assigns a default name to it. The default constraint name has the form that is shown in the following table:

arguments.name: DROP column-1 , column-2,
arguments.description: deletes each column from the table.column names a column in table-name.

arguments.name: DROP CONSTRAINT constraint-name-1 , constraint-name-2 ,
arguments.description: deletes the integrity constraint that is referenced by each constraint-name. To find the name of an integrity constraint, use the DESCRIBE TABLE CONSTRAINTS clause. (See .)

arguments.name: DROP
arguments.description: removes the foreign key constraint that is referenced by constraint-name.

arguments.name: DROP
arguments.description: removes the primary key constraint from table-name.

arguments.name: MODIFY
arguments.description: changes one or more attributes of the column that is specified in each column-definition.

statements.name: CONNECT
statements.description: Establishes a connection with a DBMS that SAS/ACCESS software supports.

arguments.name: dbms-name
arguments.description: identifies the DBMS that you want to connect to (for example, ORACLE or DB2).

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: specifies the libref for which a DBMS connection has already been established through the LIBNAME statement. The libref connection parameters can be reused in the SQL procedure using the CONNECT statement.

arguments.name: AS
arguments.description: specifies an alias that has 1 to 32 characters. The keyword AS must precede alias. Some DBMSs allow more than one connection. The optional AS clause enables you to name the connections so that you can refer to them later.

arguments.name: connect-statement-argument=
arguments.description: specifies values for arguments that indicate whether you can make multiple connections, shared or unique connections, and so on, to the database. These arguments are optional, but if they are included, then they must be enclosed in parentheses. For more information about these arguments, see .

arguments.name: database-connection-argument=
arguments.description: specifies values for the DBMS-specific arguments that are needed by PROC SQL in order to connect to the DBMS. These arguments are optional for most databases, but if they are included, then they must be enclosed in parentheses. For more information, see the SAS/ACCESS documentation for your DBMS.

statements.name: CREATE INDEX
statements.description: Creates indexes on columns in tables.
statements.help:
CREATE  <UNIQUE > INDEX  index-name
	ON  table-name (column-1 <, column-2,  ...>);

arguments.name: INDEX
arguments.description: names the index that you are creating. If you are creating an index on one column only, then index-name must be the same as column. If you are creating an index on more than one column, then index-name cannot be the same as any column in the table.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL table.

arguments.name: UNIQUE
arguments.description: causes SAS to reject any change to a table that would cause more than one row to have the same index value. Unique indexes guarantee that data in one column, or in a composite group of columns, remains unique for every row in a table. A unique index can be defined for a column that includes NULL or missing values if each row has a unique index value.

arguments.name: column
arguments.description: specifies a column in table-name.

statements.name: CREATE TABLE
statements.description: Creates PROC SQL tables.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: • in the CREATE TABLE statement, refers to the name of the table that is to be created. You can use data set options by placing them in parentheses immediately after table-name. • in the REFERENCES clause, refers to the name of table that contains the primary key that is referenced by the foreign key.

arguments.name: column-definition
arguments.description: See .

arguments.name: CHECK
arguments.description: specifies that all rows in table-name satisfy the WHERE-clause. WHERE-clause is a SAS WHERE clause. Do not include the WHERE keyword in the WHERE clause.

arguments.name: DISTINCT
arguments.description: specifies that the values of the column must be unique. This constraint is identical to UNIQUE.

arguments.name: NOT
arguments.description: specifies that the column does not contain a null or missing value, including special missing values.

arguments.name: PRIMARY
arguments.description: specifies that the column is a primary key column, that is, a column that does not contain missing values and whose values are unique.

arguments.name: REFERENCES
arguments.description: specifies that the column is a foreign key, that is, a column whose values are linked to the values of the primary key variable in another table (the table-name that is specified for REFERENCES). The referential-actions are performed when the values of a primary key column that is referenced by the foreign key are updated or deleted.

arguments.name: CASCADE
arguments.description: allows primary key data values to be updated, and updates matching values in the foreign key to the same values. This referential action is currently supported for updates only.

arguments.name: RESTRICT
arguments.description: occurs only if there are matching foreign key values. This referential action is the default.

arguments.name: SET
arguments.description: sets all matching foreign key values to NULL.

arguments.name: UNIQUE
arguments.description: specifies that the values of the column must be unique. This constraint is identical to DISTINCT.

arguments.name: table-name-2
arguments.description: creates table-name with the same column names and column attributes as table-name2, but with no rows.

arguments.name: query-expression
arguments.description: creates table-name from the results of a query.

arguments.name: constraint-name
arguments.description: specifies a name for the constraint that is being specified. The name must be a valid SAS name.

arguments.name: CHECK
arguments.description: specifies that all rows in table-name satisfy the WHERE-clause. WHERE-clause is a SAS WHERE clause. Do not include the WHERE keyword in the WHERE clause.

arguments.name: DISTINCT
arguments.description: specifies that the values of each column must be unique. This constraint is identical to UNIQUE.

arguments.name: FOREIGN
arguments.description: specifies a foreign key, that is, a set of columns whose values are linked to the values of the primary key variable in another table (the table-name that is specified for REFERENCES). The referential-actions are performed when the values of a primary key column that is referenced by the foreign key are updated or deleted.referential-actions can be the following action:

arguments.name: CASCADE
arguments.description: allows primary key data values to be updated, and updates matching values in the foreign key to the same values. This referential action is currently supported for updates only.

arguments.name: RESTRICT
arguments.description: occurs only if there are matching foreign key values. This referential action is the default.

arguments.name: SET
arguments.description: sets all matching foreign key values to NULL.

arguments.name: REFERENCES
arguments.description: specifies a foreign key, that is, a set of columns whose values are linked to the values of the primary key variable in another table (the table-name that is specified for REFERENCES). The referential-actions are performed when the values of a primary key column that is referenced by the foreign key are updated or deleted.referential-actions can be the following action:

arguments.name: CASCADE
arguments.description: allows primary key data values to be updated, and updates matching values in the foreign key to the same values. This referential action is currently supported for updates only.

arguments.name: RESTRICT
arguments.description: occurs only if there are matching foreign key values. This referential action is the default.

arguments.name: SET
arguments.description: sets all matching foreign key values to NULL.

arguments.name: NOT
arguments.description: specifies that column does not contain a null or missing value, including special missing values.

arguments.name: PRIMARY
arguments.description: specifies one or more primary key columns, that is, columns that do not contain missing values and whose values are unique.

arguments.name: UNIQUE
arguments.description: specifies that the values of each column must be unique. This constraint is identical to DISTINCT.

arguments.name: message-string
arguments.description: specifies the text of an error message that is written to the log when the integrity constraint is not met. The maximum length of message-string is 250 characters.

arguments.name: NEWLINE
arguments.description: the text that is specified for MESSAGE= is displayed as well as the default error message for that integrity constraint.

arguments.name: USER
arguments.description: only the text that is specified for MESSAGE= is displayed.

arguments.name: ORDER
arguments.description: sorts the rows in table-name by the values of each order-by-item.

statements.name: CREATE VIEW
statements.description: Creates a PROC SQL view from a query expression.

arguments.name: proc-sql-view
arguments.description: specifies the name for the PROC SQL view that you are creating.

arguments.name: query-expression
arguments.description: See .

arguments.name: column-name-list
arguments.description: is a comma-separated list of column names for the view, to be used in place of the column names or aliases that are specified in the SELECT clause. The names in this list are assigned to columns in the order in which they are specified in the SELECT clause. If the number of column names in this list does not equal the number of columns in the SELECT clause, then a warning is written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: ORDER
arguments.description: See .

arguments.name: USING
arguments.description: stores DBMS connection information in the view by embedding the SAS/ACCESS LIBNAME statement inside the view. libname-clause can be one of the following:

statements.name: DELETE
statements.description: Removes one or more rows from a table or view that is specified in the FROM clause.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies the table that you are deleting rows from. table-name can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.table name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: sas/access-view
arguments.description: specifies a SAS/ACCESS view that you are deleting rows from.

arguments.name: proc-sql-view
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL view that you are deleting rows from. proc-sql-view can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.view name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: AS
arguments.description: assigns an alias to table-name, sas/access-view, or proc-sql-view.

arguments.name: WHERE
arguments.description: See .

statements.name: DESCRIBE
statements.description: Displays a PROC SQL definition in the SAS log.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL table. table-name can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.table name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: proc-sql-view
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL view. proc-sql-view can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.view name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

statements.name: DISCONNECT
statements.description: Ends the connection with a DBMS that a SAS/ACCESS interface supports.

arguments.name: dbms-name
arguments.description: specifies the DBMS from which you want to end the connection (for example, DB2 or ORACLE). The name that you specify should match the name that is specified in the CONNECT statement.

arguments.name: alias
arguments.description: specifies the alias that is defined in the CONNECT statement.

statements.name: DROP
statements.description: Deletes tables, views, or indexes.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL table. table-name can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.table name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: view-name
arguments.description: specifies a SAS view of any type: PROC SQL view, SAS/ACCESS view, or DATA step view. view-name can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.view name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: index-name
arguments.description: specifies an index that exists on table-name.

statements.name: EXECUTE
statements.description: Sends a DBMS-specific SQL statement to a DBMS that a SAS/ACCESS interface supports.

arguments.name: dbms-SQL-statement
arguments.description: is any DBMS-specific SQL statement, except the SELECT statement, which can be executed by the DBMS-specific dynamic SQL. The SQL statement can contain a semicolon. The SQL statement can be case-sensitive, depending on your data source, and it is passed to the data source exactly as you enter it.

arguments.name: dbms-name
arguments.description: identifies the DBMS to which you want to direct the DBMS statement (for example, ORACLE or DB2).

arguments.name: alias
arguments.description: specifies an optional alias that is defined in the CONNECT statement. Note that alias must be preceded by the keyword BY.

statements.name: FROM
statements.description: Specifies source tables or views.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: names a single PROC SQL table. table-name can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.table name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks. alias specifies a temporary, alternate name for a table, view, or in-line view that is specified in the FROM clause.

arguments.name: view-name AS alias
arguments.description: names a single SAS view. view-name can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.view name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: joined-table
arguments.description: specifies a join.

arguments.name: (query-expression) AS alias (column-1 , column-2, )
arguments.description: specifies an in-line view.

arguments.name: CONNECTION
arguments.description: specifies a DBMS table.

statements.name: GROUP BY
statements.description: Specifies how to group the data for summarizing.

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: is a positive integer that equates to a column’s position.

arguments.name: column-name
arguments.description: is the name of a column or a column alias.

arguments.name: sql-expression
arguments.description: See .

statements.name: HAVING
statements.description: Subsets grouped data based on specified conditions.

arguments.name: sql-expression
arguments.description: See .

statements.name: INSERT
statements.description: Adds rows to a new or existing table or view.
statements.help:
INSERT INTO  table-name | sas/access-view | proc-sql-view <(column-1<, column-2,  ...>)>
	SET  column1=sql-expression-1 <, column-2=sql-expression-2,  ...>INSERT INTO  table-name | sas/access-view | proc-sql-view <(column-1 <, column-2,  ...>)>
	VALUES  (value-1 <, value-2,  ...>) 
		<VALUES  (value-1<, value-2,  ...>)  ...>;INSERT INTO  table-name | sas/access-view | proc-sql-view
	 <(column-1 <, column-2,  ...>)> query-expression;

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL table into which you are inserting rows. table-name can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.table name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: sas/access-view
arguments.description: specifies a SAS/ACCESS view into which you are inserting rows.

arguments.name: proc-sql-view
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL view into which you are inserting rows. proc-sql-view can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.view name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: column
arguments.description: specifies the column into which you are inserting rows.

arguments.name: sql-expression
arguments.description: See .

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: is a data value.

arguments.name: query-expression
arguments.description: See .

statements.name: INTO
statements.description: Stores the value of one or more columns for use later in another PROC SQL query or SAS statement.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: stores the values that are returned into a single macro variable.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: stores the values that are returned into a single macro variable.

arguments.name: macro-variable-1–macro-variable-n NOTRIM
arguments.description: stores the values that are returned into a range of macro variables.

arguments.name: macro-variable-1 – NOTRIM
arguments.description: stores the values that are returned into a range of macro variables.

arguments.name: macro-variable
arguments.description: specifies a SAS macro variable that stores the values of the rows that are returned.

arguments.name: NOTRIM
arguments.description: protects the leading and trailing blanks from being deleted from values that are stored in a range of macro variables or multiple values that are stored in a single macro variable.

arguments.name: SEPARATED
arguments.description: specifies a character that separates the values of the rows.

arguments.name: TRIMMED
arguments.description: trims the leading and trailing blanks from values that are stored in a single macro variable.

statements.name: ORDER BY
statements.description: Specifies the order in which rows are displayed in a result table.

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: equates to a column’s position.

arguments.name: column-name
arguments.description: is the name of a column or a column alias.

arguments.name: sql-expression
arguments.description: See .

arguments.name: ASC
arguments.description: orders the data in ascending order. This is the default order. If neither ASC nor DESC is specified, the data is ordered in ascending order.

arguments.name: DESC
arguments.description: orders the data in descending order.

statements.name: QUIT
statements.description: Executes any statements that have not executed and ends the procedure.

statements.name: RESET
statements.description: Resets PROC SQL options without restarting the procedure.

arguments.name: options
arguments.description: the PROC SQL options that you want to add, drop, or change without restarting the procedure.

statements.name: SELECT
statements.description: Lists the columns that will appear in the output.

arguments.description: represents all columns in the tables or views that are listed in the FROM clause.

arguments.name: case-expression
arguments.description: derives a column from a CASE expression.

arguments.name: column-name
arguments.description: names a single column.

arguments.name: sql-expression
arguments.description: derives a column from an sql-expression.

arguments.name: table-name.*
arguments.description: specifies all columns in the PROC SQL table that is specified in table-name.

arguments.name: table-alias.*
arguments.description: specifies all columns in the PROC SQL table that has the alias that is specified in table-alias.

arguments.name: view-name.*
arguments.description: specifies all columns in the SAS view that is specified in view-name.

arguments.name: view-alias.*
arguments.description: specifies all columns in the SAS view that has the alias that is specified in view-alias.

arguments.name: alias
arguments.description: assigns a temporary, alternate name to the column.

arguments.name: DISTINCT
arguments.description: eliminates duplicate rows. The DISTINCT argument is identical to UNIQUE.

statements.name: UPDATE
statements.description: Modifies a column's values in existing rows of a table or view.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL table. table-name can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.table name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: sas/access-view
arguments.description: specifies a SAS/ACCESS view.

arguments.name: proc-sql-view
arguments.description: specifies a PROC SQL view. proc-sql-view can be a one-level name, a two-level libref.view name, or a physical pathname that is enclosed in single quotation marks.

arguments.name: alias
arguments.description: assigns an alias to table-name, sas/access-view, or proc-sql-view.

arguments.name: column
arguments.description: specifies a column in table-name, sas/access-view, or proc-sql-view.

arguments.name: sql-expression
arguments.description: See .

statements.name: VALIDATE
statements.description: Checks the accuracy of a query expression's syntax and semantics without executing the expression.

arguments.name: query-expression
arguments.description: See .

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the output based on specified conditions.

arguments.name: sql-expression
arguments.description: See .
